definition.name: NXxbase
definition.doc: This definition covers the common parts of all monochromatic single crystal raw data application definitions.

field.name: definition
field.doc: Official NeXus NXDL schema to which this file conforms

group.name: detector

field.name: data
field.doc: The area detector data, the first dimension is always the number of scan points, the second and third are the number of pixels in x and y. The origin is always assumed to be in the center of the detector. maxOccurs is limited to the the number of detectors on your instrument.

field.name: frame_start_number
field.doc: This is the start number of the first frame of a scan. In PX one often scans a couple of frames on a give sample, then does something else, then returns to the same sample and scans some more frames. Each time with a new data file. This number helps concatenating such measurements.

field.name: orientation_matrix
field.doc: The orientation matrix according to Busing and Levy conventions. This is not strictly necessary as the UB can always be derived from the data. But let us bow to common usage which includes the UB nearly always.

field.name: unit_cell
field.doc: The unit cell, a, b, c, alpha, beta, gamma. Again, not strictly necessary, but normally written.

field.name: temperature
field.doc: The sample temperature or whatever sensor represents this value best

field.name: x_translation
field.doc: Translation of the sample along the X-direction of the laboratory coordinate system

field.name: y_translation
field.doc: Translation of the sample along the Y-direction of the laboratory coordinate system

field.name: distance
field.doc: Translation of the sample along the Z-direction of the laboratory coordinate system

field.name: mode
field.doc: Count to a preset value based on either clock time (timer) or received monitor counts (monitor).

field.name: preset
field.doc: preset value for time or monitor

group.doc: The name of this group id data if there is only one detector; if there are several the names will be data1, data2, data3 and will point to the corresponding detector groups in the instrument hierarchy.
